column1: Sawai Madhopur is a city and Municipal Council (Nagar Parishad) in the Sawai Madhopur District in Rajasthan state
column2: India. It is the administrative headquarters of Sawai Madhopur District of Rajasthan.Sawai Madhopur District comes under Bharatpur Divisional Commissionerate. Near to Sawai Madhopur is the Ranthambore National Park  which is 7 km from the railway station and Ranthambore Fort
column3: a UNESCO World Heritage Site. In Sawai Madhopur is the Trinetra Ganesh temple. Guavas are grown in the 40 km region around the city.

column1: Sawai Madhopur is located in southeast Rajasthan. It lies on the northern extension of the Vindhyan Plateau in an area of complex geology. The city is approximately 121 kilometres (75 mi) southeast of Jaipur. To the north of the town is the Banas River. To the east
column2: across the Parbati River
column3: is the large Kuno Wildlife Sanctuary of Madhya Pradesh.

column1: Sawai Madhopur was built as a planned city by Maharaja Madho Singh I of Jaipur (1751 – 1768) and is named after him. Construction began on 19 January 1763 and Sawai Madhopur celebrates its foundation day annually.

column2: now a hotel
column3: survives as a relic of the days of tiger hunting. The lodge was built in 1936 by Maharaja Man Singh II (1912 – 1971) and used as a hunting lodge until his death. The two-story building is constructed in a crescent shape with a long verandah. Queen Elizabeth of England visited the lodge in January 1961.

column2: dry climate with distinct winter
column3: summer and rainy seasons. The highest temperature occurs between May and June up to 49 °C (120 °F). The lowest temperature occurs between December and January
column4: down to 2 °C (36 °F) The average rainfall in Sawai Madhopur is 800 mm with a monsoon season from July to  October when Ranthambore National Park is closed. In summer
column5: the average humidity is 10 to 15 percent and 60 percent in the rainy season. The ideal tourist season is from November to May.

column2: Sawai Madhopur had a population of 121
column3: 106. Females counted 47 percent of the population and males 53 percent. Sawai Madhopur has an average literacy rate of 79.44 percent which is greater than the national rate of 74.04%. Female literacy (67.98 percent) is less than the male literacy rate (90.09 percent). In Sawai Madhopur
column4: 12.89 percent of the population is under 6 years of age. Sawai Madhopur includes Jat

column1: Most people in Sawai Madhopur are Hindu. Just over 20 percent are Muslim. Christians are very small minority.

The Nagar Parishad of Sawai Madhopur is the body responsible for the town's civil works and administration. The Municipal Corporation is headed by a chairman. Each of forty wards is represented in the Municipal Corporation by an elected member. The Urban Improvement Trust (UIT) of Sawai Madhopur is the government agency responsible for the planning and development of the town.
Sawai Madhopur is one of four Assembly Constituencies within Sawai Madhopur District. The others are Gangapur
column2: Bamanwas and Khandar. Sawai Madhopur lies in the Tonk-Sawai Madhopur Parliamentary Constituency. The political representative (MLA) of Sawai Madhopur is Dhanish Abrar. The Member of Parliament (MP) from Tonk-Sawai Madhopur Parliament Constituency is Sukhbir Singh Jaunapuria.

column1: The economy of Sawai Madhopur is based in agriculture and hospitality. Factors affecting the economy have included the closure of a cement factory and the instituting of regulations protecting forests and the ecosystem. There are no large scale manufacturing plants in the town.
Guava is grown around Sawai Madhopur. In 1985
column2: the first guava in the area was grown on a farm of five hectares in Karmoda Village. In 2015
column3: the retail and the wholesale markets of Guava generated more than 5 billion rupees. In 2015
column4: five thousand hectares of land were dedicated to cultivating guava.Other products from the region include those used for the extraction of essential oils and traditional medicines.

column1: The Sawai Madhopur Utsav is the annual celebration held on the foundation day of the city of Sawai Madhopur on 19 January. It is the day on which the city of Sawai Madhopur was established by Maharaja Sawai Madho Singh I in 1763.
The Ganesh Chaturthi Fair is the largest of Sawai Madhopur's fairs. It is celebrated over three days on Bhadav Shukla Chaturthi at the Ganesh Temple at the Ranthambhore Fort.
Dussera is celebrated in Sawai Madhopur for 10 days in the month of October.
The Chauth Mata Mela fair is held in the month of January
column2: at Chauth Mata temple in Chauth ka Barwara.

column1: The languages commonly spoken in Sawai Madhopur are English
column2: Hindi and Hadoti.

column1: Typical dishes in Sawai Madhopur include Dal Baati Churma
column2: Gatte ki sabzi
column3: Bajre ki roti and Dal bade. The sweet dishes includes Kharbuje ka laddoo.

column1: The types of dances performed in Sawai Madhopur include the Ghoomar dance
column2: the Sawai Madhopur dance and the  Kalbeliya dance.

column1: The cinemas in Sawai Madhopur include the Sooraj Cinema in the old city
column2: the Prem Mandir in Bazaria and the Prakash Talkies in Mantown.

column1: Ranthambore National Park is one of the largest national parks in India. It is situated about 11 kilometres (6.8 mi) from Sawai Madhopur. In 1955
column2: it was established as the Sawai Madhopur Game Sanctuary. In 1973
column3: the land became a Project Tiger reserve. The area was renamed the Ranthambore National Park in 1980. In 1984
column4: the adjacent forests were declared the Sawai Man Singh Sanctuary and Keladevi Sanctuary
column5: and in 1991 the tiger reserve was enlarged to include Sawai Man Singh and Keladevi sanctuaries.

column1: The history of Sawai Madhopur is associated with the Ranthambore Fort. The date of its construction is unknown. The fort provides an oasis in an area of arid land. In medieval times
column2: it was a defence against the forces such as those of Delhi and Agra. In 1296 CE
column3: Rao Hamir held the fort. Notable features of the fort include the Toran Dwar

column1: === Rajiv Gandhi Regional Museum of Natural History ===

column2: the foundation stone laying ceremony of Rajiv Gandhi Regional Museum of Natural History in Sawai Madhopur
column4: Vice President of India. The museum focusses on the environment of the western arid region of India.

column1: Chamatkarji Jain temple is located in Alanpur village. The temple dates back to dates back to early medieval period. The temple is build in with Pancharatha style with main shrine housing the idol of Rishabhanatha.

Shilpgram is Sawai Madhopur's rural arts and crafts complex. It is a living ethnographic museum of the West Zone of India which includes five federal states. Special emphasis is laid on workshops for children on arts
column2: crafts

column1: The Galta temple is a historic Shri Ram-Sita temple situated in the old city.

column2: the Government of India officiated an Institute of Hotel Management at Sawai Madhopur to develop the hospitality sector and to promote tourism.

Sawai Madhopur has an airstrip which is used for Private Jets and Supreme Airlines has started regular flight operations between Sawai Madhopur and Delhi from 11 April 2018. The nearest airport is the Jaipur International Airport 132 kilometres (82 mi) away.
Sawai Madhopur Junction is located on the Delhi to Mumbai trunk route. The city is a stop for many trains
column2: including Jaipur - Indore Super-Fast
column6: Marusagar Express (Ajmer - Ernakulam Express / Ernakulam Express)
column13: and the August Kranti Rajdhani Express.The Jaipur - Indore Super-Fast connects Sawai Madhopur to the major city of Madhya Pradesh
column14: Indore Junction. There is also a Jan Shatabdi Express train
column15: from Sawai Madhopur to the national capital
column16: Delhi. Other trains include the Kota - Hanumangarh Express
column17: the Sawai Madhopur-Mathura Passenger and the Jaipur-Bayana Passenger. The Kota - Patna Express connects Sawai Madhopur and Patna cities via Agra

column1: Mumbai -Nizamuddin Aug. Kranti Rajdhani Express halts at Sawai Madhopur for 2 min.
The luxury trains include the Palace on Wheels
column2: the Royal Rajasthan on Wheels
column3: and the Indian Maharaja which makes a stop at Sawai Madhopur on an eight-day round trip to tourist destinations.

column1: NH-116 (Tonk-Sawai Madhopur ) and the Kota-Lalsot Mega Highway pass through the city.
The largest circulated daily newspapers in Sawai Madhopur are the Rajasthan Patrika and Dainik Bhaskar. The All India Radio (AIR / Akashvani) and the local FM radio station
column2: 101.5 MHz broadcast in the city. Programs are broadcast in Hindi and Rajasthani.
